content: The Act is titled the "Securities Litigation Attorney Accountability and Transparency Act" and requires disclosures of payments, fee arrangements, contributions, and potential conflicts of interest between plaintiff and attorneys. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include new requirements for disclosures regarding payments in private actions. Plaintiffs and their attorneys must provide sworn certifications identifying any payments beyond the plaintiff's share. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires disclosures of payments in private actions. In private actions under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, plaintiffs and their attorneys must provide sworn certifications regarding any contributions or fee arrangements that may have influenced the selection of counsel. In private actions under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, plaintiffs and their attorneys must provide sworn certifications regarding any contributions or fee arrangements that may have influenced the selection of counsel. This includes disclosing any contributions made within five years prior to the filing of the complaint by the attorney, affiliates, or political action committees controlled by the attorney to elected officials with authority to retain counsel for the plaintiff. Additionally, plaintiffs and attorneys must provide sworn certifications regarding any other conflicts of interest in the private action. The court must determine if any conflicts of interest between the attorney and plaintiff, other than those specified, are sufficient to disqualify the attorney from representing the plaintiff. SEC. 3. SELECTION OF LEAD COUNSEL. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to require a competitive bidding process for the selection of lead counsel in legal cases, unless the court deems it infeasible. SEC. 4. STUDY OF AVERAGE HOURLY FEES IN SECURITIES CLASS ACTIONS. The Comptroller General of the United States will study and review fee awards to lead counsel in securities class actions over a 5-year period. A report must be submitted to the Senate and House committees within a year of enactment, with updated studies every 3 years. The term "securities class action" refers to private class actions under the Securities Act of 1933. Securities class action lawsuits under the Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 can be brought as plaintiff class actions following Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
